sections.heading: 1 Title
sections.text: This Act is the Education Amendment Act 2019.
This Act is the Education Amendment Act 2019.
This Act is the Education Amendment Act 2019.

sections.heading: 2 Commencement
sections.text: This Act comes into force as follows:(a) sections 4, 5, and 8 come into force on 1 January 2020:(b) the rest of this Act comes into force on the day after the date on which this Act receives the Royal assent.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: This Act comes into force as follows: sections 4, 5, and 8 come into force on 1 January 2020:(b) the rest of this Act comes into force on the day after the date on which this Act receives the Royal assent.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: This Act comes into force as follows: sections 4, 5, and 8 come into force on 1 January 2020:(b) the rest of this Act comes into force on the day after the date on which this Act receives the Royal assent.

sections.heading: 3 Principal Act
sections.text: This Part amends the Education Act 1989 (the principal Act).
This Part amends the Education Act 1989 (the principal Act).
This Part amends the Education Act 1989 (the principal Act).

sections.heading: 4 Section 2 amended (Interpretation)
sections.text: In section 2(1), insert in its appropriate alphabetical order:cohort entry policy means a policy that provides for a child who proposes to enrol in a State school or State integrated school to be assigned to a group of children and for all of the children in that group to be enrolled in the school on the same date, being a date that is determined in accordance with section 5B

In section 2(1), insert in its appropriate alphabetical order:cohort entry policy means a policy that provides for a child who proposes to enrol in a State school or State integrated school to be assigned to a group of children and for all of the children in that group to be enrolled in the school on the same date, being a date that is determined in accordance with section 5B

In section 2(1), insert in its appropriate alphabetical order:cohort entry policy means a policy that provides for a child who proposes to enrol in a State school or State integrated school to be assigned to a group of children and for all of the children in that group to be enrolled in the school on the same date, being a date that is determined in accordance with section 5B

sections.heading: 5 Sections 5 to 5B replaced
sections.text: Replace sections 5 to 5B with:5 Restrictions on primary school enrolment The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school:(a) a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.5A Cohort entry policy(1) A State school or State integrated school may adopt or revoke a cohort entry policy after complying with the requirements in section 5C.(2) A cohort entry policy must—(a) apply to all children aged 5 who have not previously enrolled in a registered school; and(b) provide that all such children may be enrolled only on a date determined in accordance with section 5B.5B Dates for starting school under cohort entry policy(1) This section applies to a school that has a cohort entry policy.(2) A child may be enrolled not earlier than the child’s fifth birthday on a date that is—(a) a term start date:(b) a mid-term start date.(3) In this section,—mid-term date means a date that is published as a mid-term date under section 5Dterm start date, in relation to a school, means a date that is the first day of a term that the school is open for instruction.

sections.heading: 5 Restrictions on primary school enrolment
sections.text: The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school:(a) a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.

sections.heading: 5 Restrictions on primary school enrolment
sections.text: The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school:(a) a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.

sections.heading: 5 Restrictions on primary school enrolment
sections.text: The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school:(a) a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school: a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: The following persons may not be enrolled in or continue to be enrolled in a primary school or a class below form 3 at a composite school: a child under the age of 5 years:(b) a child who turned 14 years of age in a previous year:(c) a child who, in the opinion of the Secretary,—(i) has completed the work of form 2; or(ii) has completed the work equivalent to form 2.

sections.heading: 5A Cohort entry policy
sections.text: (1) A State school or State integrated school may adopt or revoke a cohort entry policy after complying with the requirements in section 5C.(2) A cohort entry policy must—(a) apply to all children aged 5 who have not previously enrolled in a registered school; and(b) provide that all such children may be enrolled only on a date determined in accordance with section 5B.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (1) A State school or State integrated school may adopt or revoke a cohort entry policy after complying with the requirements in section 5C.(2) A cohort entry policy must— apply to all children aged 5 who have not previously enrolled in a registered school; and(b) provide that all such children may be enrolled only on a date determined in accordance with section 5B.
(1) A State school or State integrated school may adopt or revoke a cohort entry policy after complying with the requirements in section 5C.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (2) A cohort entry policy must— apply to all children aged 5 who have not previously enrolled in a registered school; and(b) provide that all such children may be enrolled only on a date determined in accordance with section 5B.

sections.heading: 5B Dates for starting school under cohort entry policy
sections.text: (1) This section applies to a school that has a cohort entry policy.(2) A child may be enrolled not earlier than the child’s fifth birthday on a date that is—(a) a term start date:(b) a mid-term start date.(3) In this section,—mid-term date means a date that is published as a mid-term date under section 5Dterm start date, in relation to a school, means a date that is the first day of a term that the school is open for instruction.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (1) This section applies to a school that has a cohort entry policy.(2) A child may be enrolled not earlier than the child’s fifth birthday on a date that is— a term start date:(b) a mid-term start date.(3) In this section,—mid-term date means a date that is published as a mid-term date under section 5Dterm start date, in relation to a school, means a date that is the first day of a term that the school is open for instruction.
(1) This section applies to a school that has a cohort entry policy.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (2) A child may be enrolled not earlier than the child’s fifth birthday on a date that is— a term start date:(b) a mid-term start date.

(3) In this section,—mid-term date means a date that is published as a mid-term date under section 5Dterm start date, in relation to a school, means a date that is the first day of a term that the school is open for instruction.

sections.heading: 6 New section 5D inserted (Publication of mid-term dates)
sections.text: After section 5C, insert:5D Publication of mid-term dates(1) The Minister must, before 1 July in any year, publish in the Gazette (by reference to specific dates) the mid-term start dates for the following year.(2) A mid-term start date must be the Monday that is closest to the date that is halfway between the first and last dates of a term.

sections.heading: 5D Publication of mid-term dates
sections.text: (1) The Minister must, before 1 July in any year, publish in the Gazette (by reference to specific dates) the mid-term start dates for the following year.(2) A mid-term start date must be the Monday that is closest to the date that is halfway between the first and last dates of a term.

sections.heading: 5D Publication of mid-term dates
sections.text: (1) The Minister must, before 1 July in any year, publish in the Gazette (by reference to specific dates) the mid-term start dates for the following year.(2) A mid-term start date must be the Monday that is closest to the date that is halfway between the first and last dates of a term.

sections.heading: 5D Publication of mid-term dates
sections.text: (1) The Minister must, before 1 July in any year, publish in the Gazette (by reference to specific dates) the mid-term start dates for the following year.(2) A mid-term start date must be the Monday that is closest to the date that is halfway between the first and last dates of a term.

(2) A mid-term start date must be the Monday that is closest to the date that is halfway between the first and last dates of a term.

sections.heading: 12 Section 162 amended (Establishment of institutions)
sections.text: Replace section 162(5) with:(5) In the case of a college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga, the Minister may, on the recommendation of its council, change the name of the college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga by notice published in the Gazette.(6) In the case of a university, its name may be changed if the procedure set out in subsections (7) to (9) is followed.(7) The university must give written notice to the Minister of the proposed name change.(8) If notice is given, the Minister must present the proposal to the House of Representatives.(9) If the House of Representatives, by resolution, accepts the proposed name change, the Minister must change the name of the university by notice published in the Gazette.

Replace section 162(5) with:(5) In the case of a college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga, the Minister may, on the recommendation of its council, change the name of the college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga by notice published in the Gazette.(6) In the case of a university, its name may be changed if the procedure set out in subsections (7) to (9) is followed.(7) The university must give written notice to the Minister of the proposed name change.(8) If notice is given, the Minister must present the proposal to the House of Representatives.(9) If the House of Representatives, by resolution, accepts the proposed name change, the Minister must change the name of the university by notice published in the Gazette.

Replace section 162(5) with:(5) In the case of a college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga, the Minister may, on the recommendation of its council, change the name of the college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga by notice published in the Gazette.(6) In the case of a university, its name may be changed if the procedure set out in subsections (7) to (9) is followed.(7) The university must give written notice to the Minister of the proposed name change.(8) If notice is given, the Minister must present the proposal to the House of Representatives.(9) If the House of Representatives, by resolution, accepts the proposed name change, the Minister must change the name of the university by notice published in the Gazette.

(5) In the case of a college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga, the Minister may, on the recommendation of its council, change the name of the college of education, polytechnic, specialist college, or wananga by notice published in the Gazette.
(6) In the case of a university, its name may be changed if the procedure set out in subsections (7) to (9) is followed.
(7) The university must give written notice to the Minister of the proposed name change.
(8) If notice is given, the Minister must present the proposal to the House of Representatives.
(9) If the House of Representatives, by resolution, accepts the proposed name change, the Minister must change the name of the university by notice published in the Gazette.

sections.heading: 13 Section 382 amended (Functions of Teaching Council)
sections.text: (1) After section 382(1)﻿(e), insert:(ea) to review, at any time, the criteria for teacher registration established under paragraph (e) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the criteria; or(ii) add 1 or more criteria; or(iii) delete all of the criteria and substitute new criteria:(2) After section 382(1)﻿(f), insert:(fa) to review, at any time, the standards for qualifications established under paragraph (f) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the standards; or(ii) add 1 or more standards; or(iii) delete all of the standards and substitute new standards:

sections.heading: (ea)
sections.text: (1) After section 382(1)﻿(e), insert: to review, at any time, the criteria for teacher registration established under paragraph (e) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the criteria; or(ii) add 1 or more criteria; or(iii) delete all of the criteria and substitute new criteria:(2) After section 382(1)﻿(f), insert:(fa) to review, at any time, the standards for qualifications established under paragraph (f) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the standards; or(ii) add 1 or more standards; or(iii) delete all of the standards and substitute new standards:

sections.text: (1) After section 382(1)﻿(e), insert: to review, at any time, the criteria for teacher registration established under paragraph (e) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the criteria; or(ii) add 1 or more criteria; or(iii) delete all of the criteria and substitute new criteria:

sections.heading: (fa)
sections.text: (2) After section 382(1)﻿(f), insert: to review, at any time, the standards for qualifications established under paragraph (f) and, after consultation with the Minister,—(i) vary, delete, or replace 1 or more of the standards; or(ii) add 1 or more standards; or(iii) delete all of the standards and substitute new standards:

sections.heading: 14 New section 382A inserted (Issue of statement of Government policy relating to Teaching Council’s functions)
sections.text: After section 382, insert:382A Issue of statement of Government policy relating to Teaching Council’s functions(1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.(3) Every statement of Government policy must be—(a) given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.

sections.heading: 382A Issue of statement of Government policy relating to Teaching Council’s functions
sections.text: (1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.(3) Every statement of Government policy must be—(a) given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.

sections.heading: 382A Issue of statement of Government policy relating to Teaching Council’s functions
sections.text: (1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.(3) Every statement of Government policy must be—(a) given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.

sections.heading: 382A Issue of statement of Government policy relating to Teaching Council’s functions
sections.text: (1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.(3) Every statement of Government policy must be—(a) given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.(3) Every statement of Government policy must be— given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.
(1) The Minister may, at any time, issue a statement of Government policy relating to 1 or more of the Teaching Council’s functions specified in section 382(1).
(2) Before issuing a statement of Government policy, the Minister must consult the Teaching Council.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.text: (3) Every statement of Government policy must be— given in writing to the Teaching Council; and(b) published in the Gazette; and(c) presented to the House of Representatives.

(4) A statement of Government policy comes into effect on the date specified in the Gazette notice, which date must be on or after the date of the notice and is to be treated as the date on which the statement is issued.
(5) When performing its functions, the Teaching Council must have regard to any relevant statement of Government policy.
(6) A statement of Government policy may be amended, revoked, or replaced in the same way as it is given.

(7) A statement of Government policy issued under this section is neither a legislative instrument nor a disallowable instrument for the purposes of the Legislation Act 2012, and does not have to be presented to the House of Representatives under section 41 of that Act.

sections.heading: 15 Schedule 1 amended
sections.text: In Schedule 1, after Part 7, insert:Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 201923 Interpretation In this Part,—amendment Act means the Education Amendment Act 2019commencement date means the date on which this clause comes into forcetransition period means the period beginning on the commencement date and ending on the date that is 6 months after the commencement date.24 Transitional provision in relation to criteria for registration as private school(1) A school that is provisionally or fully registered as a private school under section 35A before the commencement date—(a) is to be treated as having met the criterion specified in section 35C(h) during the transition period; and(b) must be able to show, after the expiry of the transition period, that it meets that criterion.(2) Despite subclause (1), a school that is provisionally registered under section 35A must meet the criterion specified in section 35C(h) if—(a) the school’s provisional registration is being renewed under section 35A(4); or(b) the school is being reviewed pursuant to a request made under section 35A(5); or(c) the school is being fully registered under section 35A(6).(3) An application to be registered as a private school made under section 35A before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be treated as an application received on or after the commencement date.25 Transitional provision in relation to suspension of private school(1) Any process for the suspension of a school commenced before the commencement date is to be completed under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(2) A suspension resulting from the process specified in subsection (1) is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(3) A complaint made under this Act before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.heading: 24 Transitional provision in relation to criteria for registration as private school
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) A school that is provisionally or fully registered as a private school under section 35A before the commencement date—(a) is to be treated as having met the criterion specified in section 35C(h) during the transition period; and(b) must be able to show, after the expiry of the transition period, that it meets that criterion.(2) Despite subclause (1), a school that is provisionally registered under section 35A must meet the criterion specified in section 35C(h) if—(a) the school’s provisional registration is being renewed under section 35A(4); or(b) the school is being reviewed pursuant to a request made under section 35A(5); or(c) the school is being fully registered under section 35A(6).(3) An application to be registered as a private school made under section 35A before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be treated as an application received on or after the commencement date.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) A school that is provisionally or fully registered as a private school under section 35A before the commencement date— is to be treated as having met the criterion specified in section 35C(h) during the transition period; and(b) must be able to show, after the expiry of the transition period, that it meets that criterion.(2) Despite subclause (1), a school that is provisionally registered under section 35A must meet the criterion specified in section 35C(h) if—(a) the school’s provisional registration is being renewed under section 35A(4); or(b) the school is being reviewed pursuant to a request made under section 35A(5); or(c) the school is being fully registered under section 35A(6).(3) An application to be registered as a private school made under section 35A before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be treated as an application received on or after the commencement date.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) A school that is provisionally or fully registered as a private school under section 35A before the commencement date— is to be treated as having met the criterion specified in section 35C(h) during the transition period; and(b) must be able to show, after the expiry of the transition period, that it meets that criterion.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (2) Despite subclause (1), a school that is provisionally registered under section 35A must meet the criterion specified in section 35C(h) if— the school’s provisional registration is being renewed under section 35A(4); or(b) the school is being reviewed pursuant to a request made under section 35A(5); or(c) the school is being fully registered under section 35A(6).

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (3) An application to be registered as a private school made under section 35A before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be treated as an application received on or after the commencement date.

sections.heading: 25 Transitional provision in relation to suspension of private school
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) Any process for the suspension of a school commenced before the commencement date is to be completed under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(2) A suspension resulting from the process specified in subsection (1) is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(3) A complaint made under this Act before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) Any process for the suspension of a school commenced before the commencement date is to be completed under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(2) A suspension resulting from the process specified in subsection (1) is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.(3) A complaint made under this Act before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) Any process for the suspension of a school commenced before the commencement date is to be completed under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (2) A suspension resulting from the process specified in subsection (1) is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (3) A complaint made under this Act before the commencement date, but not determined by that date, is to be dealt with under this Act as if the amendment Act had not been enacted.

sections.heading: 16 Amendments to Education Act 1964
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: This subpart amends the Education Act 1964.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: This subpart amends the Education Act 1964.

sections.heading: 17 Section 2 amended (Interpretation)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: In section 2(1), insert in its appropriate alphabetical order:correspondence school or correspondence classes means any school or institution, or any classes, established by the Minister to provide instruction by correspondence

sections.heading: 18 New section 96 inserted (Correspondence schools and classes for continuing education)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: After section 95, insert:96 Correspondence schools and classes for continuing education Having regard to the provision of continuing education, the Minister may establish any school or classes to provide instruction by correspondence for that purpose; and any school or class so established shall be controlled in such manner, and shall charge such fees for the instruction provided, as the Minister may determine.

sections.heading: 96 Correspondence schools and classes for continuing education
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: Having regard to the provision of continuing education, the Minister may establish any school or classes to provide instruction by correspondence for that purpose; and any school or class so established shall be controlled in such manner, and shall charge such fees for the instruction provided, as the Minister may determine.

sections.heading: 20 Section 2 amended (Commencement)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) Replace section 2(4) with:(4) Sections 22, 25, and 98 come into force on the date that section 20 of the Education Amendment Act 2019 comes into force.(2) Replace section 2(5) with:(5) Sections 39(4), 41(2) and (5), 43, 60, 68, and 158(2) come into force on the earlier of—(a) a date appointed by the Governor-General by Order in Council: (b) 1 January 2023.(5A) Section 95 comes into force on the date that section 20 of the Education Amendment Act 2019 comes into force.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019

sections.text: (4) Sections 22, 25, and 98 come into force on the date that section 20 of the Education Amendment Act 2019 comes into force.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (2) Replace section 2(5) with:(5) Sections 39(4), 41(2) and (5), 43, 60, 68, and 158(2) come into force on the earlier of— a date appointed by the Governor-General by Order in Council: (b) 1 January 2023.(5A) Section 95 comes into force on the date that section 20 of the Education Amendment Act 2019 comes into force.

sections.heading: (a)
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (5) Sections 39(4), 41(2) and (5), 43, 60, 68, and 158(2) come into force on the earlier of— a date appointed by the Governor-General by Order in Council: (b) 1 January 2023.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (5A) Section 95 comes into force on the date that section 20 of the Education Amendment Act 2019 comes into force.

sections.heading: 24 Section 25 amended (Section 20 replaced (New Zealand citizens and residents between 6 and 16 to go to school))
sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) In section 25, heading to new section 20, delete “or enrolling community of online learning”.(2) In section 25, replace new section 20(1) with:(1) Every person who is a New Zealand citizen or resident must, during the period beginning on the person’s sixth birthday and ending on the person’s 16th birthday, be enrolled at a registered school.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) In section 25, heading to new section 20, delete “or enrolling community of online learning”.(2) In section 25, replace new section 20(1) with:(1) Every person who is a New Zealand citizen or resident must, during the period beginning on the person’s sixth birthday and ending on the person’s 16th birthday, be enrolled at a registered school.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) In section 25, heading to new section 20, delete “or enrolling community of online learning”.

sections.part: Part 8 Provisions relating to Education Amendment Act 2019
sections.text: (1) Every person who is a New Zealand citizen or resident must, during the period beginning on the person’s sixth birthday and ending on the person’s 16th birthday, be enrolled at a registered school.
